That is how a: .17-year<ld OIFallon, Missouri sment +nd his.- pions describe the object seen near 0'Fk- Ion about 1:00 a.m.., .Friday, Augus? 235 :1.96€ The location of ?he incident was out.Cool,.,.'. .. An OIFallon city pa&dman turned with them to investigate. After severe1 minutes of searching in the field of six foot high corn, he gave up the investigation and re- -ed to town and filed his report -- no . UFO found . He did, however, pmmise to re- turn periodically and check the safety of the campers. About 45 minutes later, on a return visit, he met the trio running down the road again. This time they had spotted a pulsating light coming fm in, or through4 the woods. They said it pulsed every six seconds. They returned with the' officer fo where they had marked a tree for alignment with the-UFO and all four of them saw the . pulsating light. The officer shined .his light in its direction, but it ~eemd to havk no effect on the object. They altered their-, position and tried igain, but to nb avail. ' They never entered the wxds for safety W- sons. The incident was investigated by your ed- itor [John ~chuesslerl about 10 hpm latq. A search of the major portion of the wood$, . revealed no clues. The elevation of the , cornfield is about 500 feet. The camp br- ders a stream that also flows th~%ugh the &xis, but at an elevation of 460 feet. The night was warm and humid, but clear.
